results.title: Drugs: a primary film
results.brief_description: Presents vignettes of situations familiar to children to explore the correct use of drugs by the doctor and at home. Reveals the danger of drug misuse and emphasises the positive attitudes needed for a rich and healthy life. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Drugs, use or abuse
results.brief_description: Beginning with various types of beneficial drugs, the film moves to excessive use, stimulants and depressants, damaging chemicals in drugs, psychological dependence and forms of harmful drugs. Presents basic information about drugs and moves the viewer towards their own conclusion.

results.title: Drugs and you
results.brief_description: A unique 5-minute audio-visual tool designed to stimulate frank student discussion on drug taking. It consists of five separate 30 second TV spots, interspersed with questions programmed between each commercial.

results.title: Drugs and the nervous system. - Rev. ed.
results.brief_description: This film explains the serious disruption of the nervous system caused by drugs: aeroplane glue, stimulants (amphetamines), depressants (barbiturates, opiates), marijuana and LSD. This film is animated and is suitable for young children (Early Adolescence).

results.title: Drugs and the nervous system
results.brief_description: An animated film explaining how drugs acting on the nervous system affect the body, emphasising the danger of indiscriminate use of common drugs taking aspirin as an example. Discusses the harmful effects of narcotics, stimulants and depressants and hallucinogens. Suitable for children aged from 13 years onwards.

results.title: Drug use & young people: together we can make a difference
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Human Services and Victoria. Office of Youth Affairs
results.brief_description: Terry Laidler presents the second in a series of interactive seminars linking a Statewide panel via satellite to 25 rural centres. The Victorian Premier’s Drug Advisory Council report forms the basis of discussion surrounding the issue of youth drug use in Victoria. The panel includes The Hon. Denis Napthine, Minister, Youth & Community Services, Professor Greg Whelan, Alcohol and Drug Unit, St. Vincent’s Hospital, Robert Bellhouse, a writer of drug education material for use in schools and Peter Wearne, director of Theos Youth Centre (St. Kilda) with 20 years experience working with young people in crisis. During the seminar, the panel fields questions from studio participants, by fax and telephone.

results.title: Drug abuse: one town's answer
results.creator_credit: Pat Shields and Charles Cahill and Associates
results.brief_description: The story of the Awareness House concept, as begun in Fort Bragg, California, which provides a meaningful alternative to drugs. “Turn on to people, not drugs”. Ex-addicts, who are experienced drug specialists, provide counselling and realistic drug abuse information. The teenagers involved talk freely about their reasons for giving up narcotics.

results.title: Drown-proofing
results.creator_credit: Norman Keziere, Joe Hayward and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Outdoor Education and Recreation”.
Designed to help teach swimmers and non-swimmers alike how to survive a water accident, by showing how to stay afloat and travel in water, even if you have never learned to swim. The majority of men and women can remain on the surface in fresh water, and in salt water the human body is even more buoyant.
